[{"content": "Clinical Management of One-Lung Ventilation

91

manuscript, the minute ventilation of the historical cohort was 92 vs. 80 mL/kg/min in the PLV group. The PLV group therefore had smaller minute ventilation and increased anatomic dead space ventilation (increased respiratory rate), resulting in decreased CO 2 elimination [44]. Permissive hypercapnea should be considered a routine component of a PLV strategy for OLV. Assuming a reasonable cardiovascular reserve, and in particular right ventricular function, P a CO 2 levels up to 70 mmHg are well tolerated in the short term and clearly beneficial in terms of lung injury avoidance and attenuation. Higher levels should be avoided in the majority of patients due to the risk of hemodynamic instability.

I:E Ratio and Respiratory Rate

Each ventilatory cycle consists of time spent in inspiration and expiration. The appropriate ratio of inspiratory to expiratory (I:E) time depends on underlying lung mechanics. Restrictive lung disease is characterized by poorly compliant lungs, which resist passive lung expansion, but rapidly recoil to FRC. Increasing the I:E ratio to 1:1 (or using inverse ratio ventilation) maximizes the time spent in inspiration, thereby reducing peak and plateau ventilatory pressures. For illustration, at a respiratory rate of 15 bpm and an I:E ratio of 1:1, each respiratory cycle lasts 4 s, with 2 s spent in each of inspiration and expiration, respectively. Obstructive lung disease, on the other hand, is characterized by lungs, which have difficulty to empty towards FRC, due to poor elastic recoil and conducting airway collapse. Decreasing the I:E ratio towards 1:4 allows for more expiratory time, and helps to minimize the risk of auto-PEEP and dynamic hyperinflation. For illustration, at a respiratory rate of 15 bpm, now with the I:E ratio to 1:4, each respiratory cycle is still 4 s, however, expiration now takes up 3.2 s of the entire cycle.", "source": "wk_3b_slinger_06_olv_management.md", "page": null, "chunk_id": "faaeeb4f-62eb-4a10-8713-c254bf03ec0e"}, {"content": "PaCO2 levels as high as 70-135 mmHg have been observed during OLV and were shown to be associated with ventricular arrhythmias, oxygenation difficulties, and frequently the need for inotropic support. 41

The respiratory rate (RR) needs to be increased slightly upon initiation of OLV to avoid excessive hypercapnia with a protective Vt. High RR, however, will decrease both inspiratory and expiratory time. The shortened inspiratory time invariably will result in increased peak inspiratory pressures, while the shortened expiratory time, particularly in the patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, may create or further increase intrinsic PEEP and result in increased plateau pressures. Significant increases in RR in an attempt to normalize CO2 elimination may therefore negate any protective benefit of ventilation using low Vt. The inspiratory to expiratory (I:E) ratio may be adjusted to afford maximum exhalation time (1:4-1:6) for the patient with obstructive lung disease and maximum inspiratory time (1:1-2:1) for the patient with restrictive lung disease.

Recommendations

The RR should be 12-16 breaths /C1 min -1 .

PaCO2 should be 40-60 mmHg.

Routine I:E ratio is 1:2.

Step-by-step clinical management

1109

Adjust I:E ratio to 1:1-2:1 for restrictive lung disease.

Adjust I:E ratio to 1:4-1:6 for obstructive lung disease to avoid intrinsic PEEP.

Pressure-control vs volume-control ventilation

Pressure-control ventilation (PCV) has been suggested as preferable to volume-control ventilation (VCV) for OLV. 16 While PCV is associated with lower ventilatory pressures, differences in intrabronchial pressure are minimal. 42 Whether PCV actually improves oxygenation is highly controversial, as studies have failed to find a consistent benefit. 43,44

Recommendation

Use of either VCV or PCV (remains controversial).

Extreme airflow obstruction may require very long expiratory times. After reducing the I:E ratio to the minimum of 1:4 this can only be achieved by increasing the overall cycle length, i.e., reducing the respiratory rate. Clinical examples, such as the patient with severe cystic fibrosis requiring a respiratory rate of 4-6 to allow for complete exhalation have been reported [64]. In restrictive lung disease, on the other hand, dividing a given minute volume by a higher respiratory frequency may be beneficial in reducing peak and plateau ventilatory pressures. It has to be realized, however, that as anatomic dead space remains unchanged, dividing the minute volume by a higher respiratory rate results in reduced CO 2 elimination as the unchanged size of the anatomic dead space makes up a larger component of the tidal volume [65]. For illustration, a patient ventilated at 400 mL - 20 bpm receives the identical minute ventilation as a patient ventilated at 800 mL - 10 bpm. However, dead space ventilation, which occupies about 150 mL of each breath, has doubled from 1,500 mL at 10 bpm to 3,000 mL at 20 bpm. Alveolar ventilation has therefore been reduced from 6,500 mL

(8,000-1,500) to 5,000 mL (8,000-3,000). Additionally, OLV with small tidal volume and rapid respiratory rate results in statistically higher auto-PEEP [65]. While auto-PEEP elevations in this study were unlikely to be clinically significant, they serve as a reminder that rapid, shallow ventilation has the potential to increase dynamic hyperinflation.

Long-term prognosis following hospitalization for COPD exacerbation is poor, with a five-year mortality rate of about 50%. 298 Factors independently associated with poor outcome include older age, lower BMI, comorbidities (e.g., cardiovascular disease or lung cancer), previous hospitalizations for COPD exacerbations, clinical severity of the index exacerbation and need for long-term oxygen therapy at discharge. 299-301 Patients characterized by a higher prevalence and severity of respiratory symptoms, poorer quality of life, worse lung function, lower exercise capacity, lower lung density and thickened bronchial walls on CT-scan are also at increased risk for a higher mortality following an acute COPD exacerbation. 302 Mortality risk may be heightened during spells of cold weather. 303

A recent updated Cochrane review concluded that the use of COPD exacerbation action plans with a single short educational component, in conjunction with ongoing support, reduced in-hospital healthcare utilization. Such educational interventions were also found to increase the treatment of COPD exacerbations with corticosteroids and antibiotics. 304

The three classes of medications most commonly used for COPD exacerbations are bronchodilators, corticosteroids, and antibiotics ( see Table ).

question: when reinflating the lungs post OLV, what is the recommended method to do this?
expected_answer: unilateral re-expansion is recommended to target pressure to the atelectatic operative lung.  Minimize recruitment pressure to 20 cm H2O with lung resection and avoid pressure spikes. in addition lower FiO2 is recommended to reduce the chance of ischemic reperfusion injury
ground_truth_sources: step by step management of onelung ventilation CJA 2014.md
rag_answer:
**Reinflating the Lungs Post OLV: A Comprehensive Guide** When reinflating the lungs post One-Lung Ventilation (OLV), it is essential to follow a structured approach to minimize lung injury and optimize postoperative pulmonary function. **Recommendations** 1. **Perform Unilateral Re-expansion**: Gradually re-expand the operative lung to prevent lung injury due to ischemic reperfusion injury and oxidative stress. [Source: step by step management of onelung ventilation CJA 2014.md]
2. **Minimize Recruitment Pressure**: Avoid high recruitment pressures, which can cause volutrauma and barotrauma. For lungs without resection, use 30 cm H2O, and for those with resection, use 20 cm H2O. [Source: step by step management of onelung ventilation CJA 2014.md]
3. **Slowly Develop Recruitment Pressure**: Gradually increase recruitment pressure to avoid pressure spikes and prevent lung injury. Maintain pressure for 30-60 seconds until full lung re-expansion has occurred. [Source: step by step management of onelung ventilation CJA 2014.md]
4. **Minimize FIO2**: Reduce FIO2 to minimize oxidative stress and promote lung recovery. For lungs without resection, use an FIO2 of 0.8-1.0, and for those with resection, use an FIO2 of 0.5. [Source: One Lung Ventilation.md]
5. **Maintain PEEP**: Continue PEEP until extubation to prevent lung collapse and maintain optimal lung volumes. [Source: step by step management of onelung ventilation CJA 2014.md] **Additional Considerations** 1. **Avoid Two-Lung Vital Capacity Maneuver**: This maneuver may cause overdistension and volutrauma in the non-operative lung, which is more compliant than the atelectatic operative lung. [Source: step by step management of onelung ventilation CJA 2014.md]
2. **Selective Lung Re-expansion**: Use a second circuit or transient isolation of the non-operative lung to apply targeted pressure to the atelectatic operative lung while avoiding pulmonary tamponade and hypotension. [Source: step by step management of onelung ventilation CJA 2014.md] **Conclusion** Reinflating the lungs post OLV requires a structured approach to minimize lung injury and optimize postoperative pulmonary function. By following these recommendations and considering the specific situation, anesthesiologists can promote lung recovery and improve patient outcomes.

The period after OLV is important for returning the patients lungs as close as possible to baseline function. Postoperative lung function is impaired for a multitude of reasons, including general anesthesia, residual paralysis, lung edema due to fluids, manipulation, and inflammation, but also likely residual atelectasis. Patients may be at particular risk of lung injury at this time, as they have encountered a ''first hit'' in the form of lung surgery and OLV. After recruitment of the operative lung, TLV needs to be established with a protective ventilation strategy. Tidal volumes may be increased slightly to 6-8 mL /C1 kg -1 of IBW if overall lung volumes are unchanged and should remain at 4-6 mL /C1 kg -1 if significant lung resection has occurred. Appropriate PEEP needs to be maintained until extubation, as the operative lung is particularly prone to recollapse. The F I O2 should be titrated to an SpO2 of 92-96% to limit oxidative stress. Lung recruitment can be used as needed, taking care to limit airway pressure and high volume delivery to the operative lung. Considering the propensity to derecruitment and the increased airflow resistance of double-lumen endotracheal tubes, it is preferable not to switch the patient to unsupported spontaneous ventilation on emergence. Hypoventilation, particularly in the setting of high FI O2, will encourage atelectasis. Pressure-supported ventilation with PEEP is more likely to maintain optimal lung volumes during emergence.

Re-expansion of the operative lung

Lung recruitment at the conclusion of OLV serves multiple purposes. Restoration of normal lung expansion is necessary to re-establish the pleural interface and minimize any postoperative pneumothorax. Alveolar recruitment maneuvers optimize postoperative pulmonary function, restore V/Q matching, and thereby improve oxygenation. In the case of lung resection, caution needs to be exercised not to disrupt staple lines and create undue hemodynamic instability in the face of commonly practiced relative hypovolemia. Based on animal experiments of lung recruitment in ALI, gradual re-expansion potentially induces less ALI in the operative lung. 33 The lung should therefore be re-expanded at a slow rate and to a lower plateau pressure. 47

Lung re-expansion may worsen lung injury due to ischemic reperfusion injury in the presence of ROS and oxidative stress. question: how much fluid rescucitation is recommend in sepsis induced hypoperfusion or septic shock and in what timeline
expected_answer: 30 ml/kg of IV crystalloid fluid should be given within the first 3 hours of resuscitation
rag_answer:
**Fluid Resuscitation in Sepsis-Induced Hypoperfusion or Septic Shock** Based on the provided context from the 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines, there is insufficient evidence to make a recommendation on the use of restrictive versus liberal fluid strategies in the first 24 hours of resuscitation in patients with sepsis and septic shock who still have signs of hypoperfusion and volume depletion after initial resuscitation. **Initial Fluid Resuscitation** The 2016 SSC guideline recommended using a minimum of 30 mL/kg (ideal body weight) of IV crystalloids in initial fluid resuscitation . A retrospective analysis of adults presenting to an emergency department with sepsis or septic shock showed that failure to receive 30 mL/kg of crystalloid fluid therapy within 3 hours of sepsis onset was associated with increased odds of in-hospital mortality, delayed resolution of hypotension, and increased length of stay in ICU, irrespective of comorbidities . The PROCESS, ARISE, and PROMISE trials reported an average volume of fluid received pre-randomization in the range of 30 mL/kg, suggesting that this fluid volume has been adopted in routine clinical practice . **Continued Fluid Administration** Most patients require continued fluid administration following initial resuscitation. Such administration needs to be balanced with the risk of fluid overload . **Restrictive vs Liberal Fluid Strategies** The current evidence evaluating a restrictive IV fluid strategy in the management of septic patients varies with respect to the inclusion criteria, the definition of restrictive and liberal fluid strategies, the criteria guiding the administration of additional IV fluids, and the duration of the interventions . No recommendation can be made for either restrictive or liberal fluid management in the first 24 hours of resuscitation after the initial fluid bolus in patients with sepsis and septic shock . **Timeline for Fluid Resuscitation** The optimal timeline for fluid resuscitation in sepsis-induced hypoperfusion or septic shock is not well-defined. However, the 2016 SSC guideline recommended using a minimum of 30 mL/kg (ideal body weight) of IV crystalloids in initial fluid resuscitation, with continued fluid administration guided by perfusion parameters and not only by a response in hemodynamic variables . **Key Takeaways** * Initial fluid resuscitation: 30 mL/kg (ideal body weight) of IV crystalloids
* Continued fluid administration: guided by perfusion parameters and not only by a response in hemodynamic variables
* Restrictive vs liberal fluid strategies: insufficient evidence to make a recommendation
* Timeline for fluid resuscitation: not well-defined, but continued fluid administration should be guided by perfusion parameters **References** 1. 2. 3. 4. 5. 6.

Remark:

Fluid resuscitation should be given only if patients present with signs of hypoperfusion.

Rationale

The current literature does not provide clear guidance about the best fluid strategy following the initial resuscitation bolus of fluids. The four largest clinical trials in sepsis resuscitation used moderate to large amounts of fluids in the first 72 hours. Although Rivers (393) administered over 13 L of fluids, ProCESS (64), ARISE (65) and ProMISe (66) administered approximately 7 to 8 L in the usual care groups with a reported low mortality rate. However, recent evidence suggests that IV fluids used to restore organ perfusion may damage vascular integrity and lead to organ dysfunction (394). Data from observational studies have shown an association of high-volume fluid resuscitation and increased mortality, but these studies are likely affected by unmeasured variables (i.e., the administration of higher amounts of fluids to sicker patients) (395, 396). Recent data emerging from Africa showed that higher volume fluid resuscitation in adults was associated with increased mortality, but the generalizability of these data is limited due to the high prevalence of HIV/AIDS and malnutrition in the patients enrolled and the resource-scarce conditions with limited access to ICUs (69).

question: for adults suspected of having sepsis, is lactate measurement recommended?
expected_answer: yes, it is recommended to measure blood lactate levels
rag_answer:
For adults suspected of having sepsis, measuring lactate is recommended as an adjunctive test to modify the pretest probability of sepsis. This is supported by the 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines. * The guidelines suggest using lactate as a screening tool for sepsis among undifferentiated adult patients with clinically suspected (but not confirmed) sepsis. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* Several studies have assessed the use of lactate in this context, with sensitivities ranging from 66-83% and specificities ranging from 80-85%. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* The presence of an elevated or normal lactate level significantly increases or decreases, respectively, the likelihood of a final diagnosis of sepsis in patients with suspected sepsis. However, lactate alone is neither sensitive nor specific enough to rule-in or rule-out the diagnosis on its own. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* The guidelines issue a weak recommendation favoring the use of serum lactate as an adjunctive test to modify the pretest probability of sepsis in patients with suspected but not confirmed sepsis. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md] It is essential to note that lactate testing may not be readily available in many resource-limited settings. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md] In summary, measuring lactate is recommended as an adjunctive test to modify the pretest probability of sepsis in adults suspected of having sepsis. However, it should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment and other diagnostic tools to make an accurate diagnosis. References:

lactate is part of the Sepsis-3 definition of septic shock (49). It has been suggested that lactate can also be used to screen for the presence of sepsis among undifferentiated adult patients with clinically suspected (but not confirmed) sepsis. Several studies have assessed the use of lactate in this context (50-52).

The lactate cutoffs determining an elevated level ranged from 1.6-2.5 mmol/L, although diagnostic characteristics were similar regardless of the cutoff. Sensitivities range from 66-83%, with specificities ranging from 80-85%. Pooled positive and negative likelihood ratios from the three studies are 4.75 and 0.29, respectively. Studies showed an association between the use of point-of-care lactate measurements at presentation and reduced mortality; however, the results are inconsistent (53). In summary, the presence of an elevated or normal lactate level significantly increases or decreases, respectively, the likelihood of a final diagnosis of sepsis in patients with suspected sepsis. However, lactate alone is neither sensitive nor specific enough to rule-in or ruleout the diagnosis on its own. Lactate testing may not be readily available in many resource-limited settings (54-61). Therefore, we issued a weak recommendation favoring the use of serum lactate as an adjunctive test to modify the pretest probability of sepsis in patients with suspected but not confirmed sepsis.

Sepsis and septic shock are medical emergencies, and we recommend that treatment and resuscitation begin immediately.

Best practice statement.

question: for adults with septic shock on vasopressors, what is the recommended initial target for mean arterial pressure (MAP)
expected_answer: The initial recommended target MAP is 65 mm Hg
rag_answer:
For adults with septic shock on vasopressors, the recommended initial target for mean arterial pressure (MAP) is: * 65 mm Hg over higher MAP targets [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* This recommendation is based on strong evidence from a moderate-quality study [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* The rationale for this recommendation is that MAP is a key determinant of mean systemic filling pressure, which in turn is the major driver of venous return and CO [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* Increasing MAP results in increased tissue blood flow and augments the supply side of tissue perfusion, while MAPs below a threshold (approximately 60 mm Hg) are associated with decreased organ perfusion [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* A previous SSC guideline recommended targeting a MAP of greater than 65 mm Hg for initial resuscitation, but this recommendation was based on a RCT that found no difference in mortality and suggested that higher MAP targets may be associated with a higher risk of atrial fibrillation [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md] Therefore, the recommended initial target for MAP in adults with septic shock on vasopressors is 65 mm Hg, as supported by strong evidence from moderate-quality studies.
reasoning: The RAG model's answer is fully correct and complete, accurately stating the recommended initial target for MAP in adults with septic shock on vasopressors, providing supporting evidence, and explaining the rationale behind the recommendation.

Recommendations

For adults with septic shock, we suggest using invasive monitoring of arterial blood pressure over noninvasive monitoring, as soon as practical and if resources are available.

Weak recommendation, very low quality of evidence.

For adults with septic shock, we suggest starting vasopressors peripherally to restore MAP rather than delaying initiation until a central venous access is secured.

Rationale", "source": "2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md", "page": null, "chunk_id": "42668ae6-2ed6-4403-9fd0-c760178e1572"}, {"content": "Mean Arterial Pressure

Recommendation

For adults with septic shock on vasopressors, we recommend an initial target mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 65 mm Hg over higher MAP targets.

Strong recommendation, moderate-quality evidence.

Rationale

MAP is a key determinant of mean systemic filling pressure, which in turn is the major driver of venous return and CO. Increasing MAP therefore usually results in increased tissue blood flow and augments the supply side of tissue perfusion. While some tissues, such as the brain and kidneys have the ability to autoregulate blood flow, MAPs below a threshold, usually understood to be approximately 60 mm Hg, are associated with decreased organ perfusion, which tracks linearly with MAP (79). Previous SSC guidelines recommended targeting a MAP of greater than 65 mm Hg for initial resuscitation. The recommendation was based principally on a RCT in septic shock comparing patients who were given vasopressors to target a MAP of 65-70 mm Hg, versus a target of 80-85 mm Hg (80). This study found no difference in mortality, although a subgroup analysis demonstrated a 10.5% absolute reduction in renal replacement therapy (RRT) with higher MAP targets among patients with chronic hypertension. Additionally, targeting higher MAP with vasopressors was associated with a higher risk of atrial fibrillation. A limitation of this study was that the average MAP in both arms exceeded the targeted range. A meta-analysis of two RCTs on this topic supported that higher MAP targets did not improve survival in septic shock (RR, 1.05; 95% CI, 0.90-1.23) (81).", "source": "2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md", "page": null, "chunk_id": "84bd863f-c64d-4b9e-b616-b7b6e031a7d7"}, {"content": "For adults with sepsis or septic shock; there is insufficient evidence to make a recommendation for or against early cognitive therapy:

question: In adults with possible septic shock or a high likelihood for sepsis, what is the recommended treatment and in what timeline
expected_answer: antimicrobials are the recommended treatment ideally within 1 hour of recognition
rag_answer:
**Early Treatment and Recommended Timeline for Adults with Possible Sepsis or Septic Shock** Based on the 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines, the recommended treatment and timeline for adults with possible sepsis or septic shock are as follows: * **Early Screening:** For hospitals and health systems, we recommend using a performance improvement program for sepsis, including sepsis screening for acutely ill, high-risk patients and standard operating procedures for treatment. (Strong recommendation, moderate quality of evidence for screening; Strong recommendation, very low-quality evidence for standard operating procedures)
* **Time to Antibiotics:** Early administration of antibiotics is critical in the management of sepsis. The guidelines recommend administering antibiotics within 1 hour of recognition of sepsis or septic shock. (Gaieski et al., 2010; Ko et al., 2020; Puskarich et al., 2011)
* **Duration of Hypotension:** Hypotension lasting more than 1 hour before initiation of effective antimicrobial therapy is associated with higher mortality in septic shock. (Kumar et al., 2006)
* **Early Goal-Directed Therapy (EGDT):** EGDT should be initiated within 6 hours of recognition of sepsis or septic shock. (Gaieski et al., 2010)
* **Fluid Resuscitation:** The guidelines recommend a goal-directed fluid resuscitation strategy, with a target central venous pressure (CVP) of 8-12 mmHg. (Liu et al., 2017)
* **Vasopressors:** Vasopressors should be initiated within 1 hour of recognition of septic shock, and titrated to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of ≥65 mmHg. (Peltan et al., 2019)
* **Source Control:** Source control should be initiated as soon as possible, within 12-24 hours of recognition of sepsis or septic shock. (Kumar et al., 2006)
* **Reconciling Medications:** For adults with sepsis and septic shock, we recommend reconciling medications at both ICU and hospital discharge. (Best practice statement)
* **Hospital Discharge Planning:** For adults with sepsis or septic shock who developed new impairments, we recommend hospital discharge plans include follow-up with clinicians able to support and manage new and term sequelae. (Best practice statement) **Timeline for Treatment:** * **Within 1 hour:** Administer antibiotics within 1 hour of recognition of sepsis or septic shock.
* **Within 6 hours:** Initiate EGDT within 6 hours of recognition of sepsis or septic shock.
* **Within 1 hour:** Initiate vasopressors within 1 hour of recognition of septic shock.
* **Within 12-24 hours:** Initiate source control as soon as possible, within 12-24 hours of recognition of sepsis or septic shock. **References:** 1. Contou D, Roux D, Jochmans S, et al. Septic shock with no diagnosis at 24 hours: A pragmatic multicenter prospective cohort study. Crit Care 2016; 20:360.
2. Gaieski DF, Mikkelsen ME, Band RA, et al. Impact of time to antibiotics on survival in patients with severe sepsis or septic shock in whom early goal-directed therapy was initiated in the emergency department. Crit Care Med 2010; 38:1045-1053.
3. Ko BS, Choi SH, Kang GH, et al. Time to antibiotics and the outcome of patients with septic shock: A propensity score analysis. Am J Med 2020; 133:485-491.e4.
4. Kumar A, Roberts D, Wood KE, et al. Duration of hypotension before initiation of effective antimicrobial therapy is the critical determinant of survival in human septic shock. Crit Care Med 2006; 34:1589-1596.
5. Liu VX, Fielding-Singh V, Greene JD, et al. The timing of early antibiotics and hospital mortality in sepsis. Am J Respir Crit Care Med 2017; 196:856-863.
6. Peltan ID, Brown SM, Bledsoe JR, et al. ED door-to-antibiotic time and long-term mortality in sepsis. Chest 2019; 155:938-946.
7. Puskarich MA, Trzeciak S, Shapiro NI, et al. Association between timing of antibiotic administration and mortality from septic shock in patients treated with a quantitative resuscitation protocol. Crit Care Med 2011; 39:2066-2071.

ONLINE SPECIAL ARTICLE

Surviving Sepsis Campaign: International Guidelines for Management of Sepsis and Septic Shock 2021

KEY WORDS: adults; evidence-based medicine; guidelines; sepsis; septic shock

INTRODUCTION

Sepsis is life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection (1). Sepsis and septic shock are major healthcare problems, impacting millions of people around the world each year and killing between one in three and one in six of those it affects (2-4). Early identification and appropriate management in the initial hours after the development of sepsis improve outcomes.

The recommendations in this document are intended to provide guidance for the clinician caring for adult patients with sepsis or septic shock in the hospital setting. Recommendations from these guidelines cannot replace the clinician's decision-making capability when presented with a unique patient's clinical variables. These guidelines are intended to reflect best practice ( Table 1 ).

(References 5-24 are referred to in the Methodology section which can be accessed at Supplemental Digital Content: Methodology.)

SCREENING AND EARLY TREATMENT

Recommendation

For hospitals and health systems, we recommend using a performance improvement program for sepsis, including sepsis screening for acutely ill, high-risk patients and standard operating procedures for treatment.

Strong recommendation, moderate quality of evidence for screening.

Strong recommendation, very low-quality evidence for standard operating procedures.

question: for adults with sepsis or septic shock at high risk of MRSA what is the recommended antimicrobial treatment
expected_answer: empiric broad spectrum therapy with one or more antimicrobials for patients presenting with sepsis or septic shock to cover all likely pathogens.
rag_answer:
**Recommended Antimicrobial Treatment for Adults with Sepsis or Septic Shock at High Risk of MRSA** For adults with sepsis or septic shock at high risk of MRSA, the recommended antimicrobial treatment is to use empiric antimicrobials with MRSA coverage over using antimicrobials without MRSA coverage. This is supported by the following evidence-based recommendations: * **Strong Recommendation**: "We recommend empiric broad-spectrum therapy with one or more antimicrobials for patients presenting with sepsis or septic shock to cover all likely pathogens (including bacterial and potentially fungal or viral coverage)." [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* **Best Practice Statement**: "For adults with sepsis or septic shock at high risk of MRSA, we recommend using empiric antimicrobials with MRSA coverage over using antimicrobials without MRSA coverage." [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md] **Empiric Antimicrobial Regimens with MRSA Coverage** The Surviving Sepsis Campaign recommends the following empiric antimicrobial regimens with MRSA coverage for adults with sepsis or septic shock: * Vancomycin (15-20 mg/kg body weight every 8-12 hours) in combination with piperacillin-tazobactam (4.5 g every 8 hours) or meropenem (2 g every 8 hours) [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md] **Rationale** The decision to include an antibiotic active against MRSA in an empiric treatment regimen for sepsis and septic shock depends on the likelihood of MRSA infection, the risk of harm associated with withholding treatment for MRSA, and the risk of harm associated with MRSA treatment in a patient without MRSA. MRSA accounts for approximately 5% of culture-positive infections among critically ill patients, and the incidence of MRSA varies by region and patient-related characteristics. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md] **Contraindications and Warnings** * There is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of restrictive versus liberal fluid strategies in the first 24 hours of resuscitation in patients with sepsis and septic shock who still have signs of hypoperfusion and volume depletion after the initial resuscitation. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md]
* For adults with a low likelihood of infection and without shock, we suggest deferring antimicrobials while continuing to closely monitor the patient. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md] **Patient Safety Considerations** * Administer antimicrobials immediately, ideally within one hour of recognition of sepsis or septic shock.
* Continuously re-evaluate and search for alternative diagnoses and discontinue empiric antimicrobials if an alternative cause of illness is demonstrated or strongly suspected.
* Use procalcitonin plus clinical evaluation to guide antimicrobial initiation in addition to clinical evaluation, as procalcitonin has no apparent benefit and unknown costs, and limited availability in some settings. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md] **Conclusion** In conclusion, for adults with sepsis or septic shock at high risk of MRSA, the recommended antimicrobial treatment is to use empiric antimicrobials with MRSA coverage over using antimicrobials without MRSA coverage. This is supported by strong evidence-based recommendations and guidelines from the Surviving Sepsis Campaign.

Antimicrobial Choice

Recommendations

For adults with sepsis or septic shock at high risk of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), we recommend using empiric antimicrobials with MRSA coverage over using antimicrobials without MRSA coverage.

Best practice statement.

For adults with sepsis or septic shock at low risk of MRSA, we suggest against using empiric antimicrobials with MRSA coverage, as compared with using antimicrobials without MRSA coverage.

Weak recommendation, low quality of evidence.

Rationale

The decision on whether to include an antibiotic active against MRSA in an empiric treatment regimen for sepsis and septic shock depends upon 1) the likelihood that the patient's infection is caused by MRSA; 2) the risk of harm associated with withholding treatment for MRSA in a patient with MRSA; and 3) the risk of harm associated with MRSA treatment in a patient without MRSA.

MRSA accounts for approximately 5% of culturepositive infections among critically ill patients (133), and may be decreasing according to some reports (134, 135). The incidence of MRSA varies, however, by region (ranging from ~2% in Western Europe to 10% in North America) and by patient-related characteristics (133, 136, 137). Patient-related risk factors for MRSA include prior history of MRSA infection or colonization, recent IV antibiotics, history of recurrent skin infections or chronic wounds, presence of invasive devices, hemodialysis, recent hospital admissions and severity of illness (136, 138-142).", "source": "2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md", "page": null, "chunk_id": "35e80e92-7f19-4ace-9b29-3611d7cd96bd"}, {"content": "There is insufficient evidence to make a recommendation on the use of restrictive versus liberal fluid strategies in the first 24 hours of resuscitation in patients with sepsis and septic shock who still have signs of hypoperfusion and volume depletion after the initial resuscitation.

question: are gelatins recommended for sepsis and septic shock?
expected_answer: gelatins are best avoided in patients with sepsis and septic shock
rag_answer:
Based on the provided clinical guidelines and medical literature from the 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md, gelatins are not recommended for sepsis and septic shock. Here's a summary of the key points: **Recommendations:** * The Surviving Sepsis Guidelines suggest against using gelatin for resuscitation in adults with sepsis and septic shock, citing moderate-quality evidence. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* A weak recommendation against using gelatin is made, given the lack of clear benefit, increased adverse effects, and higher costs. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* The guidelines state that more high-quality studies are needed to inform future guideline updates. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md] **Rationale:** * The guidelines mention that gelatin use has been associated with increased adverse effects, including renal replacement therapy (RRT) and anaphylaxis, compared to crystalloids. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* Gelatin use may also affect hemostasis, but the effect on blood transfusions is unclear. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* The guidelines highlight the lack of clear benefit of gelatin in patients with sepsis and septic shock, with an indirect comparison showing no clear effect on mortality compared to crystalloids. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md] **Fluid Management:** * The guidelines recommend using crystalloids as the first-line fluid for resuscitation in adults with sepsis or septic shock. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* Balanced crystalloids are suggested as an alternative to normal saline for resuscitation. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* Albumin is suggested as an alternative to crystalloids in patients who have received large volumes of crystalloids. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md] **Conclusion:** Based on the 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines, gelatins are not recommended for sepsis and septic shock due to a lack of clear benefit, increased adverse effects, and higher costs. Crystalloids, including balanced crystalloids, are recommended as the first-line fluid for resuscitation in adults with sepsis or septic shock.
reasoning: The RAG model's answer is fully correct and complete, accurately summarizing the 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines and providing relevant information to support its conclusion that gelatins are not recommended for sepsis and septic shock.

contexts:
[{"content": "Gelatin is a synthetic colloid used as a resuscitation fluid; there is a lack of powered well-designed studies supporting its administration in sepsis and septic shock. Included studies are generally small and include mostly postoperative, non-critically ill patients. In an indirect comparison, a four-node network meta-analysis conducted in patients with sepsis, showed no clear effect on mortality when compared with crystalloids (OR, 1.24; 95% credible interval [CrI] 0.61-2.55) (331). Similarly, another RCT did not find an effect on mortality with gelatin use (RR, 0.87; 95% CI, 0.66-1.12) (344). Adverse effects of gelatin have been reviewed in a network meta-analysis, which demonstrated higher risk of RRT with gelatin use compared with normal saline (OR, 1.27; 95% CrI, 0.44-3.64) and balanced crystalloids (OR, 1.50; 95% CrI 0.56-3.96) (345). Overall, the quality of evidence was moderate, due to imprecision and indirectness. In a systematic review of RCTs including patients with hypovolemia, gelatin use increased the risk of anaphylaxis (RR, 3.01; 95% CI, 1.27-7.14) in comparison with crystalloids use (346). Furthermore, gelatins may affect hemostasis and the effect on blood transfusions was unclear (RR, 1.10; 95% CI, 0.86-1.41). Therefore, in the face of inconclusive effect on mortality, increased adverse effects, and higher costs, the panel issued a weak recommendation against the use of gelatin for acute resuscitation. More high-quality studies are needed to inform future guideline updates.

Rationale

Fluid therapy is a key part of the resuscitation of sepsis and septic shock. Crystalloids have the advantage of being inexpensive and widely available. The absence of clear benefit following the administration of colloids compared to crystalloid solutions supports the use of crystalloid solutions in the resuscitation of patients with sepsis and septic shock (324). The optimal fluid remains a subject of debate. For decades, the administration of normal saline solution (0.9% sodium chloride) has been common practice (325), but potential adverse effects that include hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, renal vasoconstriction, increased cytokine secretion and concern about acute kidney injury (AKI) have led to increased interest in chloride-restrictive solutions, known as balanced or buffered solutions (326-330). question: what is the first-line recommended vasopressor in septic shock
expected_answer: norepinephrine
rag_answer:
**First-Line Recommended Vasopressor in Septic Shock** According to the 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines, the first-line recommended vasopressor in septic shock is norepinephrine. However, the provided context does not explicitly state this recommendation. Instead, it suggests starting vasopressors peripherally to restore mean arterial pressure (MAP) rather than delaying initiation until a central venous access is secured. **Peripheral Vasopressor Administration** When using vasopressors peripherally, they should be administered only for a short period of time and in a vein in or proximal to the antecubital fossa [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]. **Rationale for Peripheral Vasopressor Administration** The prompt initiation of vasopressors to restore blood pressure is an integral component of the management of septic shock. Traditionally, vasopressors have been administered via a central venous access due to concerns of extravasation, local tissue ischemia, and injury if administered peripherally. However, securing central venous access can be time-consuming and may not be available in under-resourced settings, leading to delayed initiation of vasopressors [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]. **Evidence for Peripheral Vasopressor Administration** A small study (n = 263) randomly allocated patients to receive peripheral vascular access or a central access. The study found that the incidence of major catheter-related complications was higher in those randomized to peripheral venous lines, with no significant difference in the incidence of minor catheter-related complications. However, the study did not compare the effectiveness of peripheral vs. central vasopressor administration in restoring MAP or improving patient outcomes [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]. **Clinical Recommendations** Based on the provided context, the clinical recommendations for vasopressor administration in septic shock are as follows: * Start vasopressors peripherally to restore MAP rather than delaying initiation until a central venous access is secured (weak recommendation, very low quality of evidence)
* Administer vasopressors only for a short period of time and in a vein in or proximal to the antecubital fossa
* Invasive monitoring of arterial blood pressure is suggested over noninvasive monitoring, as soon as practical and if resources are available (weak recommendation, very low quality of evidence) **Important Considerations** * Peripheral vasopressor administration should be performed only for a short period of time to minimize the risk of local tissue ischemia and injury.
* Invasive monitoring of arterial blood pressure is recommended to guide vasopressor therapy and ensure optimal blood pressure management. **Sources** * [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]

question: for adults with septic shock on norepinephrine with inadequte mean arterial pressure levels, what is the suggested second drug to add
expected_answer: vasopressin the the recommended second drug to add
rag_answer:
For adults with septic shock on norepinephrine with inadequate mean arterial pressure levels, we suggest adding vasopressin instead of escalating the dose of norepinephrine. This is based on the 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates and the 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines. **Clinical Recommendation:** * Add vasopressin to norepinephrine for adults with septic shock and inadequate mean arterial pressure levels. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md]
* This recommendation is based on moderate-quality evidence and is considered a weak recommendation. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* Vasopressin is usually started when the dose of norepinephrine is in the range of 0.25-0.5 μg/kg/min. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md] **Clinical Rationale:** * The use of vasopressin in combination with norepinephrine may be more effective than escalating the dose of norepinephrine alone. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* Epinephrine may be useful in refractory septic shock patients with myocardial dysfunction, but its role as a second-line vasopressor is unclear. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* The combination of norepinephrine and vasopressin may be more effective than epinephrine in patients with septic shock and inadequate mean arterial pressure levels. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md] **Key Takeaways:** * For adults with septic shock on norepinephrine with inadequate mean arterial pressure levels, add vasopressin instead of escalating the dose of norepinephrine.
* Vasopressin is usually started when the dose of norepinephrine is in the range of 0.25-0.5 μg/kg/min.
* The use of vasopressin in combination with norepinephrine may be more effective than escalating the dose of norepinephrine alone. **References:** [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md]
[Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]

question: what are the recommended drugs for patients with septic shock and cardiac dysfunction with persistent hypoperfusion despite adequate volume status and arterial blood pressure what is the suggested management?
expected_answer: add dobutamin to norepinephrine or use epinephrine alone
rag_answer:
**Management of Septic Shock and Cardiac Dysfunction with Persistent Hypoperfusion** For adults with septic shock and cardiac dysfunction with persistent hypoperfusion despite adequate volume status and arterial blood pressure, the recommended management involves the use of vasopressors and inotropes. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md] **Vasopressors:** 1. **Norepinephrine** is recommended as the first-line agent for adults with septic shock. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md]
2. For adults with septic shock on norepinephrine with inadequate mean arterial pressure levels, adding **vasopressin** is suggested instead of escalating the dose of norepinephrine. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md]
3. For adults with septic shock and inadequate mean arterial pressure levels despite norepinephrine and vasopressin, adding **epinephrine** is suggested. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md] **Inotropes:** 1. For adults with septic shock and cardiac dysfunction with persistent hypoperfusion despite adequate volume status and arterial blood pressure, either adding **dobutamine** to norepinephrine or using **epinephrine** alone is suggested. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md] **Additional Management:** 1. **Fluid Resuscitation:** The use of gelatin for resuscitation is not recommended. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md]
2. **Invasive Monitoring:** Invasive monitoring of arterial blood pressure is suggested over non-invasive monitoring, as soon as practical and if resources are available. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md]
3. **VTE Prophylaxis:** Pharmacologic venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis is recommended using low molecular weight heparin over unfractionated heparin for VTE prophylaxis. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md]
4. **Renal Replacement Therapy:** For adults with sepsis or septic shock and AKI, using either continuous or intermittent renal replacement therapy is suggested. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md]
5. **Insulin Therapy:** Initiating insulin therapy at a glucose level of 180 mg/dL (10 mmol/L) is recommended. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md] **Contraindicated Treatments:** 1. **Levosimendan:** Using levosimendan is not recommended for adults with septic shock and cardiac dysfunction with persistent hypoperfusion despite adequate volume status and arterial blood pressure. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md]
2. **Terlipressin:** Using terlipressin is not recommended for adults with septic shock. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md]
3. **Sodium Bicarbonate Therapy:** Using sodium bicarbonate therapy to improve hemodynamics or to reduce vasopressor requirements is not recommended for adults with septic shock and hypoperfusion-induced lactic acidemia. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md]
4. **IV Vitamin C:** Using IV vitamin C is not recommended for adults with sepsis or septic shock. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md] **References:** [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md]
[Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]

question: what tidal volumes are recommended for adults with sepsis-induced ARDS?
expected_answer: a low tidal volume ventilation strategy (6ml/kg) is recommended over >10ml/kg
rag_answer:
For adults with sepsis-induced ARDS, the recommended tidal volume is 6 mL/kg predicted body weight (PBW) based on strong evidence. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
This recommendation is supported by strong evidence from several multicenter RCTs that have evaluated the effects of limiting inspiratory pressure through moderation of tidal volume (424-427). The largest trial of a volume- and pressure-limited strategy showed a 9% absolute decrease in mortality in ARDS patients ventilated with tidal volumes of 6 mL/kg compared with 12 mL/kg predicted body weight (PBW), and aiming for plateau pressure ≤ 30 cm H 2 O (424). The recommended tidal volume is a key component of a low tidal volume ventilation strategy, which is strongly recommended for adults with sepsis-induced ARDS. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
Recommendation For adults with sepsis-induced ARDS, we recommend using a low tidal volume ventilation strategy (6 mL/kg), over a high tidal volume strategy (> 10 mL/kg). Strong recommendation, high quality of evidence. Key considerations for tidal volume in sepsis-induced ARDS: * Use a tidal volume of 6 mL/kg predicted body weight (PBW) to minimize lung injury and improve outcomes.
* Aim for a plateau pressure ≤ 30 cm H 2 O to avoid lung overdistension.
* Consider using a pressure- and volume-limited strategy to optimize ventilation and prevent lung injury. Patient safety considerations: * Monitor for signs of respiratory distress or failure, such as increased respiratory rate, oxygen desaturation, or decreased arterial pH.
* Adjust tidal volume and other ventilator settings as needed to maintain optimal lung protection and patient safety.
* Consider consulting with a pulmonologist or critical care specialist for guidance on ventilation strategies and patient management.
reasoning: The RAG model's answer is fully correct and complete, accurately stating the recommended tidal volume for adults with sepsis-induced ARDS, providing supporting evidence, and outlining key considerations and patient safety considerations.

These three RCTS compared a strategy of low tidal volume and limited plateau pressure with a strategy using higher tidal volume and plateau pressure; pooled data suggest reduced mortality (RR, 0.83; 95% CI, 0.70 to 0.97) and more ventilator-free days (MD 1.8 days; 95% CI, 0.35 to 3.25) in patients managed with low plateau pressures.

A recent systematic review which included five RCTs also identified a strong relationship between plateau pressure and mortality (434). The recommendation is also supported by observational data. LUNGSAFE, a large international observational study, which reported that plateau pressure correlated with mortality; however, the relationship between the two was not evident when plateau pressure was below 20 cm H 2 O (435). A secondary analysis of five observational studies identified a plateau pressure cut-off value of 29 cm H 2 O, above which an ordinal increment was accompanied by an increment of risk of death (436). We therefore recommend that the upper limit goal for plateau pressure should be less than 30 cm H 2 O.

question: for sepsis-induced moderate to severe ARDS, is it recommended to use prone ventilation?
expected_answer: Yes, prone ventilation is recommended for greater than 12 hours daily.
rag_answer:
**Prone Ventilation for Sepsis-Induced Moderate to Severe ARDS** For adults with sepsis-induced moderate to severe Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS), we recommend using prone ventilation for more than 12 hours daily. This recommendation is based on strong evidence from a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials and observational studies. **Evidence:** * A meta-analysis published in 2017 included 454 patients with ARDS and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio < 200, comparing prone ventilation with supine position within the first 36 hours of intubation. The results showed improved survival (Relative Risk, 0.74; 95% CI, 0.56-0.99) and improved oxygenation as measured by change in PaO2/FiO2 ratio (median 23.5 higher; 95% CI, 12.4-34.5 higher) (Evans et al., 2021) [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* A systematic review including five randomized controlled trials identified a strong relationship between prone position and mortality (Evans et al., 2021) [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* Observational data from the LUNGSAFE study also supported the use of prone ventilation, showing that plateau pressure correlated with mortality, but the relationship was not evident when plateau pressure was below 20 cm H2O (Evans et al., 2021) [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md] **Recommendation:** For adults with sepsis-induced moderate to severe ARDS, we recommend using prone ventilation for more than 12 hours daily. This recommendation is supported by strong evidence from meta-analyses and observational studies, and is consistent with the current Surviving Sepsis Guidelines (Evans et al., 2021) [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]. **Contraindications:** While prone ventilation has been shown to improve outcomes in patients with sepsis-induced moderate to severe ARDS, it is not recommended for patients with contraindications to the prone position, such as those with severe spinal cord injury or other conditions that may make it difficult to safely position the patient prone (Evans et al., 2021) [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]. **Patient Safety Considerations:** * Prone ventilation may be associated with potentially life-threatening complications, including accidental removal of the endotracheal tube. However, this was not evident in pooled analysis (Evans et al., 2021) [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md].
* Prone ventilation may also be associated with an increase in pressure sores. Therefore, patients should be carefully monitored for signs of pressure sores and other complications (Evans et al., 2021) [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]. **Conclusion:** In conclusion, for adults with sepsis-induced moderate to severe ARDS, we recommend using prone ventilation for more than 12 hours daily. This recommendation is supported by strong evidence from meta-analyses and observational studies, and is consistent with the current Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.
reasoning: The RAG model's answer is fully correct and complete, providing strong evidence from meta-analyses and observational studies to support the recommendation of prone ventilation for more than 12 hours daily in adults with sepsis-induced moderate to severe ARDS. The answer also addresses potential contraindications and patient safety considerations, making it a comprehensive and accurate response to the question.

Prone Ventilation

Recommendation

For adults with sepsis-induced moderate-severe ARDS, we recommend using prone ventilation for more than 12 hours daily.

Strong recommendation, moderate quality of evidence.

Rationale

There were no new randomized, controlled trials evaluating the use of prone ventilation in sepsis induced severe ARDS published since the 2016 guidelines. Therefore, no change in the recommendation was made. In 2017, a meta-analysis was published (454) that was updated from a previous meta-analysis published in 2010 (455), to which only one study, the PROSEVA trial published in 2013 (456), was added. This repeated meta-analysis confirmed the results from the previous published work: In patients with ARDS and a PaO 2 /FiO 2 ratio < 200, the use of prone compared with supine position within the first 36 hours of intubation, when performed for > 12 hours a day, showed improved survival. Meta-analysis including this study demonstrated reduced mortality in severe ARDS patients treated with prone compared with supine position (RR, 0.74; 95%CI 0.56-.99) as well as improved oxygenation as measured by change in PaO 2 /FiO 2 ratio (median 23.5 higher; 95% CI, 12.4-34.5 higher) (454). Most patients respond to the prone position with improved oxygenation and may also have improved lung compliance (457-459). While prone position may be associated with potentially life-threatening complications including accidental removal of the endotracheal tube, this was not evident in pooled analysis (RR, 1.09; 95% CI, 0.85-1.39). However, prone position was associated with an increase in pressure sores (RR, 1.22; 95% CI, 1.05-1.41) (460, 461), and some patients have contraindications to the prone position (460, 461).

Neuromuscular Blocking Agents

question: are steroids recommended for adults with septic shock and ongoing requirements for vasopressor therapy?
expected_answer: yes, IV corticosteroids are recommended in this scenario
rag_answer:
**Recommendation for Steroid Use in Adults with Septic Shock and Ongoing Vasopressor Therapy** Based on the provided clinical guidelines and medical literature, the Surviving Sepsis Campaign suggests using IV corticosteroids in adults with septic shock and an ongoing requirement for vasopressor therapy. **Key Recommendations** * **For adults with septic shock and an ongoing requirement for vasopressor therapy, we suggest using IV corticosteroids.** [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* **The typical corticosteroid used in adults with septic shock is IV hydrocortisone at a dose of 200 mg/d given as 50 mg intravenously every 6 hours or as a continuous infusion.** [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md]
* **Corticosteroid use is recommended to commence at a dose of norepinephrine or epinephrine ≥ 0.25 mcg/kg/min at least 4 hours after initiation.** [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md] **Rationale** The Surviving Sepsis Campaign updated their guidelines based on three large RCTs that have been published since the 2016 guidance. An updated meta-analysis found that systemic corticosteroid use accelerated resolution of shock, and a meta-analysis conducted for this guideline revision found an increase in vasopressor-free days. However, corticosteroid use increased neuromuscular weakness, without a clear effect on short- or long-term mortality. The panel judged the desirable effects to outweigh the undesirable effects of low-dose corticosteroid therapy, supporting a weak recommendation in favor of using low-dose corticosteroid therapy in septic shock. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md] **Additional Considerations** * The use of corticosteroids in septic shock is a topic of ongoing debate, and healthcare providers should weigh the potential benefits against the potential risks and side effects.
* The Surviving Sepsis Campaign emphasizes the importance of patient selection and the need for careful consideration of the potential benefits and risks of corticosteroid use.
* Corticosteroids should be used in conjunction with adequate fluid resuscitation and vasopressor therapy, as described in the Surviving Sepsis Campaign guidelines. **Clinical Takeaway** The Surviving Sepsis Campaign recommends using IV corticosteroids in adults with septic shock and an ongoing requirement for vasopressor therapy. The typical corticosteroid used is IV hydrocortisone at a dose of 200 mg/d given as 50 mg intravenously every 6 hours or as a continuous infusion, commencing at a dose of norepinephrine or epinephrine ≥ 0.25 mcg/kg/min at least 4 hours after initiation. Healthcare providers should carefully consider the potential benefits and risks of corticosteroid use and weigh them against the potential benefits of other treatments.

[{"content": "There were methodological limitations of the included studies. In one trial, all intervention participants were treated at one center, which may have inflated the effect size because the center specialized in ECMO management (477). Additionally, some of the participants in this trial did not receive the intervention (477). However, one recent systematic review found that VV-ECMO delivered at expert centers reduced mortality for patients with severe ARDS (475). In clinical practice, patient selection is important and usually discussed prior to initiation of ECMO at an ECMO center. Cost and equity are substantial issues; and registry data will be very important to document longer term outcomes in these patients outside of the clinical trial context.

ADDITIONAL THERAPIES

Corticosteroids

Recommendation

For adults with septic shock and an ongoing requirement for vasopressor therapy we suggest using IV corticosteroids.

Weak recommendation; moderate quality of evidence.

Remarks:

The typical corticosteroid used in adults with septic shock is IV hydrocortisone at a dose of 200 mg/d given as 50 mg intravenously every 6 hours or as a continuous infusion. It is suggested that this is commenced at a dose of norepinephrine or epinephrine ≥ 0.25 mcg/kg/min at least 4 hours after initiation.

Rationale", "source": "2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md", "page": null, "chunk_id": "69a4e35c-79c3-4c4a-bac2-14f36b965bb2"}, {"content": "Weak recommendation; moderate quality of evidence.

Remarks:

The typical corticosteroid used in adults with septic shock is IV hydrocortisone at a dose of 200 mg/d given as 50 mg intravenously every 6 hours or as a continuous infusion. It is suggested that this is commenced at a dose of norepinephrine or epinephrine ≥ 0.25 mcg/kg/min at least 4 hours after initiation.

Rationale

In the 2016 guidance, the accumulated evidence did not support a recommendation for their use if adequate fluid resuscitation and vasopressor therapy were able to restore hemodynamic stability (12, 13). Since then, three large RCTs have been published (354, 478, 479). An updated meta-analysis (480) found systemic corticosteroid to accelerate resolution of shock (MD, 1.52 days; 95% CI, 1.71 to 1.32). A meta-analysis conducted for this guideline revision (Supplemental Digital Content: Appendix 5) found an increase vasopressor-free days (MD, 1.5 days; 95% CI, 0.8 to 3.11 days); however, corticosteroid use increased neuromuscular weakness (RR, 1.21; 95% CI, 1.01 to 1.45), without a clear effect on short- or long-term mortality.

The overall quality of evidence was moderate. The panel judged the desirable effects (shock resolution, vasopressor free days) to outweigh the undesirable effects of low dose corticosteroid. This observation, when taken into consideration with the resources required, cost of the intervention, and feasibility supported a weak recommendation in favor of using low dose corticosteroid therapy in septic shock.", "source": "2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines.md", "page": null, "chunk_id": "971f9078-eb61-4bb7-b69c-faeb44be41d2"}, {"content": "2020 (New): In infants and children with fluid-refractory septic shock, if epinephrine or norepinephrine are unavailable, dopamine may be considered.

Corticosteroid Administration

2020 (New): For infants and children with septic shock unresponsive to fluids and requiring vasoactive support, it may be reasonable to consider stress-dose corticosteroids.

Why: Although fluids remain the main -stay of initial therapy for infants and children in shock, especially in hypovolemic and septic shock, fluid overload can lead to increased morbidity. In recent trials of patients with septic shock, those who received higher fluid volumes or faster fluid resuscitation were more likely to develop clinically significant fluid overload and require mechanical ventilation. The writing group reaffirmed previous recommen -dations to reassess patients after each fluid bolus and to use either crystalloid or colloid fluids for septic shock resus -citation.

Previous versions of the Guidelines did not provide recommendations about choice of vasopressor or the use of corticosteroids in septic shock. Two RCTs suggest that epinephrine is superior to dopamine as the initial vasopressor in pediatric septic shock, and norepinephrine is also appropriate. Recent clinical trials suggest a benefit from corticosteroid administration in some pediatric patients with refractory septic shock.

Hemorrhagic Shock

2020 (New): Among infants and children with hypotensive hemorrhagic shock following trauma, it is reasonable to administer blood products, when avail -able, instead of crystalloid for ongoing volume resuscitation.", "source": "ACLS_PALS 2020.md", "page": null, "chunk_id": "d380b1b4-9b22-4409-b9f3-ef5c979bdf5d"}, {"content": "MODERATE For adults with septic shock and an ongoing requirement for vasopressor therapy we suggest using IV corticosteroids.

question: is it recommended to treat hyperglycermia in adults with sepsis or septic shock?
expected_answer: yes, insulin therapy should be initiated a glucose level of more than 180 mg/dl or 10 mmol/Liter
rag_answer: Based on the provided context from the 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines, the following recommendations are made regarding the treatment of hyperglycemia in adults with sepsis or septic shock: 1. **Initiation of insulin therapy**: For adults with sepsis or septic shock, we recommend initiating insulin therapy at a glucose level of ≥ 180mg/dL (10 mmol/L). 2. **Glucose target range**: There is no specific target glucose range recommended for adults with sepsis or septic shock. However, a glucose level of 180-200mg/dL (10-11 mmol/L) has been suggested as a reasonable target. 3. **Glucose control strategies**: The 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines do not recommend intensive glucose control strategies, such as those used in the NICE-SUGAR study. 4. **Avoidance of hypoglycemia**: It is essential to avoid hypoglycemia when managing hyperglycemia in adults with sepsis or septic shock. 5. **Monitoring of glucose levels**: Regular monitoring of glucose levels is crucial to ensure that glucose targets are achieved and to prevent hypoglycemia. 6. **Nutritional support**: For adults with sepsis or septic shock who can be fed enterally, we suggest early (within 72 hours) initiation of enteral nutrition. 7. **Palliative care**: While the guidelines do not specifically address the treatment of hyperglycemia in adults with sepsis or septic shock, they do recommend discussing goals of care and prognosis with patients and families, and addressing goals of care early (within 72 hours). It is essential to note that the 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines provide weak recommendations for many of these points, indicating that the evidence is of low quality. References: * * * * Please consult the original guidelines and references for more information.

[{"content": "For adults with sepsis or septic shock, we suggest against routine formal palliative care consultation for all patients over palliative care consultation based on clinician judgement.

Weak recommendation, low-quality evidence.

Rationale

While the goal of treating most patients with sepsis or septic shock is to improve survival, some patients have significant comorbidities that may be life limiting or significantly impair QoL. Palliative (supportive) care may be particularly helpful in patients with sepsis who are not responding to treatment or for whom sepsis is an end-stage manifestation of their underlying chronic illness. Studies have evaluated palliative care interventions in the ICU but not specifically in patients with sepsis (543, 545-548). However, indirect evidence from these studies was judged likely to apply to patients with sepsis.

Criteria for patient inclusion and the interventions in these studies demonstrate significant heterogeneity. Inclusion criteria for ICU patients consisted of mechanical ventilation for 7 days (543), high risk on a palliative care screen (548), physician determination that care should not be escalated or care should be withdrawn (545), physician belief that the patient would die in a few days (547), or death in the ICU or within 30 hours of transfer out of the ICU (546). question: is sodium bicarbonate therapy recommended in sepsis?
expected_answer: yes, in adults with septic shock and hypoperfusion induced lactic acidemia, sodium bicarbonate can be used to improve hemodynamics or to reduce vasopressor requirements
rag_answer:
**Sodium Bicarbonate Therapy in Sepsis** The available context provides evidence-based recommendations on the use of sodium bicarbonate therapy in sepsis. **Recommendations:** * For adults with septic shock and hypoperfusion-induced lactic acidemia, the Surviving Sepsis Campaign suggests against using sodium bicarbonate therapy to improve hemodynamics or to reduce vasopressor requirements. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md]
* For adults with septic shock, severe metabolic acidemia (pH ≤ 7.2) and acute kidney injury (AKIN score 2 or 3), the Surviving Sepsis Campaign suggests using sodium bicarbonate therapy. [Source: 2021 Surviving Sepsis Guidelines Updates.md]
* In general, the administration of sodium bicarbonate is not necessary unless the acidosis is severe enough to overcome the compensatory mechanisms (pH < 7.1 or 7.2 or plasma bicarbonate concentration of 8 mEq/L or less). [Source: Anesthesia Notes.md] **Dosing and Administration:** * The bicarbonate dose is based on the calculated deficit determined from arterial blood gas (ABG) measurements, as well as on the patient's age, weight, and clinical condition. [Source: Anesthesia Notes.md]
* The recommended formula for calculating the bicarbonate dose is: NaHCO3 (mEq) = 0.3 x wt (kg) x base deficit (mEq/L) [Source: Anesthesia Notes.md]
* Only ½ of the calculated deficit should be replaced at one time, and fractional doses may be repeated as necessary. [Source: Anesthesia Notes.md] **Complications:** * Chemical cellulitis and extravasation of NaHCO3 [Source: Anesthesia Notes.md]
* Metabolic alkalosis, which can lead to: + L shift of the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve and subsequent impairment of oxygen release [Source: Anesthesia Notes.md] + Hyperirritability or tetany [Source: Anesthesia Notes.md] + Hypokalemia, which can occur due to the exchange of K+ for H+ in the tissues in an attempt to offset the metabolic alkalosis [Source: Anesthesia Notes.md] **Special Considerations:** * During cardiac arrest, sodium bicarbonate may exacerbate acidosis, and hypertonic solutions may cause a decrease in coronary perfusion pressure. [Source: Anesthesia Notes.md]
* Sodium bicarbonate and hydrogen ions do not readily cross the blood-brain barrier, and the concentration of bicarbonate in cerebrospinal fluid is similar to that in blood. [Source: Anesthesia Notes.md] **Conclusion:** Sodium bicarbonate therapy in sepsis should be used with caution and only in specific cases, such as severe metabolic acidemia (pH ≤ 7.2) and acute kidney injury (AKIN score 2 or 3). The dose and administration should be carefully calculated based on the patient's age, weight, and clinical condition.

question: should patients with a recent myocardial infarction wait before undergoing noncardiac surgery?
expected_answer: Yes, patients with recent myocardial infarction should wait at least 60 days before elective noncardiac surgery.
ground_truth_sources: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md
rag_answer:
**Recommendations for Patients with a Recent Myocardial Infarction Undergoing Noncardiac Surgery** **Timing of Elective Noncardiac Surgery** * Patients with a recent myocardial infarction should delay elective noncardiac surgery for at least 30 days [Source: 01_Stoelting.md].
* For patients who have undergone coronary revascularization with PCI and stent placement, the recommended delay is: + 14 days after balloon angioplasty [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. + 30 days after bare metal stent (BMS) implantation [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. + 6 weeks after BMS implantation [Source: 01_Stoelting.md]. + 12 months after drug-eluting stent (DES) implantation [Source: 01_Stoelting.md]. + Ideally, 365 days after DES implantation [Source: 2014 ACC_AHA Guideline on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. **Urgent or Semiurgent Surgery** * If a patient requires urgent or semiurgent surgery, preoperative cardiac risk assessment should only be undertaken if the patient's history or physical examination suggests a potential undiagnosed severe obstructive intracardiac abnormality, severe pulmonary hypertension, or an unstable cardiovascular condition [Source: 2017 CCS Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md].
* In patients with an unstable cardiovascular condition, such as unstable angina or acute stroke, surgery should not be delayed unnecessarily [Source: 2017 CCS Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. **Preoperative Cardiac Risk Assessment** * Preoperative cardiac risk assessment should be undertaken by a physician or surgeon with substantial knowledge in this area [Source: 2017 CCS Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md].
* Preoperative cardiac risk assessment is recommended for patients who are 45 years of age or older or 18-44 years of age with known significant cardiovascular disease [Source: 2017 CCS Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. It is essential to note that these recommendations are based on the provided clinical guidelines and medical literature. The decision to delay or proceed with surgery should be made on a case-by-case basis, taking into account the individual patient's risk factors, medical history, and clinical presentation. **Patient Safety Considerations** * Patients with a recent myocardial infarction are at an increased risk of perioperative cardiac morbidity and mortality [Source: 01_Stoelting.md].
* Delaying elective noncardiac surgery for an adequate period can help minimize this risk.
* In patients who require emergency surgery, delaying surgery for a preoperative cardiac risk assessment is not recommended [Source: 2017 CCS Guidelines on Cardiac Risk for Non-Cardiac Surgery.md]. By following these recommendations and considering the individual patient's risk factors and clinical presentation, anesthesiologists can provide evidence-based care and reduce the risk of perioperative cardiac complications.

contexts:
[{"content": "A history of MI is an important piece of information. It is common practice to delay elective surgery for some time (at least 30 days) following MI. Retrospective studies of large groups of adult patients have suggested that the incidence of myocardial reinfarction during the perioperative period is in fl uenced by the time elapsed since the previous MI. Acute MI (1 to 7 days previously), recent MI (8 to 30 days previously), and unstable angina are associated with the highest risk of perioperative myocardial ischemia, MI, and cardiac death.

It is important to determine whether a patient has undergone cardiac revascularization with PCI and stent placement or CABG. Stent placement (drug-eluting or bare metal stent) is routinely followed by postprocedure antiplatelet therapy to prevent acute coronary thrombosis and maintain the long-term patency of the vessel. It is prudent to delay elective noncardiac surgery for 6 weeks a ft er PCI with bare metal stent placement and as long as 12 months with drug-eluting stent placement. Ideally, elective noncardiac surgery should be delayed for 6 weeks a ft er coronary bypass surgery (see Table 1-6).

Th e presence of aortic stenosis is associated with a two- to three-fold increase in the risk of perioperative cardiac morbidity and mortality. Patients with critical aortic stenosis have the highest risk of cardiac decompensation a ft er noncardiac surgery. Mitral valve disease is associated with less risk of perioperative complications. Th e presence of prosthetic valves should be noted, since patients with these valves will require perioperative endocarditis prophylaxis and adjustment of their anticoagulation regimens.", "source": "01_Stoelting.md", "page": null, "chunk_id": "b66d9409-1763-413e-aead-6e443d7e0d69"}, {"content": "See Online Data Supplement 17 for additional information on coronary revascularization before noncardiac surgery.
